Christina Salcido , vice president of mission operations , said members ' names , birth dates , home addresses , insurance policy numbers and health history information could have been accessed from Sept 30 to Oct 1 . Out of an abundance of caution , we are notifying everyone whose email was in this email account , Salcido wrote in the letter . <S1> On the day the organization became aware of the breach </S1> , <S2> IT services changed the password and determined it was secure </S2> , Salcido wrote . <S4> The Girl Scouts of Orange County reviewed the account , eliminated all personal information it contained and notified the California attorney general ' s office of the breach </S4> .

data.annotated_text: INDIANAPOLIS ' Officials at Scotty ' s Brewhouse are scrambling to deal with <S1> a data breach that leaked thousands of employee W-2 forms to an unknown scammer </S1> . That 's according to our news reporting partners at CBS4 Indy . <S3> Company officials called police about the leak Monday afternoon </S3> . <S4> Somebody posing as CEO Scott Wise emailed a payroll employee , asking her to send all 4,000 W-2 forms to him </S4> . <S5> The e-mail wasn ' t really from Wise , but the employee did send all the forms , giving the scammer personal finance information for all those employees </S5> . <S0> Scotty ' s Brewhouse executives contacted the IRS and Indianapolis Metropolitan Police Department about the breach </S0> . <S2> They ' re now working to notify all their employees and give them steps to protect their financial information </S2> . IMPD and other agencies are involved in the investigation into who sent the bogus email . <E6> This email scam matches a phishing scheme that prompted a warning from the IRS last year during tax season </E6> . At that time , the agency recorded a 400 percent increase in this kind of scam .

data.annotated_text: <S0> On January 20 , an email from Lynn Jurich , CEO of San Francisco-based solar firm Sunrun , popped up in a payroll department employee 's inbox </S0> . <E4> The CEO was requesting copies of all employee W-2 forms , which were about to be sent out in preparation for tax season </E4> . <S2> The employee responded quickly as requested , not realizing the W-2 forms ' containing the addresses , social security numbers , and salary information for Sunrun 's nearly 4,000 employees ' were actually being delivered to a scam artist </S2> . <E5> Tax season is always a busy time for scammers seeking to gain access to sensitive information </E5> , but <S1> this year attacks are coming earlier and in greater numbers than usual </S1> . <E6> The uptick </E6> has caused <E7> the IRS to release an urgent alert warning employers to be on the lookout for what they 're refering to as `` one of the most dangerous email phishing scams we ' ve seen in a long time </E7> . '' <E8> By using email spoofing techniques , criminals are able to draft emails that look as though they are coming directly from a high-level executive at your organization </E8> .
